channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Afghanistan Is in Chaos. Is That What Hamid Karzai Wants?
item.media:description: Hamid Karzai, the former president of Afghanistan, at his compound in Kabul last month.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Critics say the former president is working from the wings to destabilize his successor’s government. He says he has no interest in returning to power.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Kashmiri Faces Sedition Charges Over Facebook Activity
item.media:description: An Indian patrol on a street in Srinagar, Kashmir, on Tuesday.
item.description: Tauseef Ahmad Bhat, 29, was accused of “liking, sharing and posting anti-India content on Facebook,” a police official said.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: A.N.C. Loses Pretoria, South Africa’s Capital, as Setbacks Mount
item.description: It was clear Saturday that the party of Nelson Mandela had suffered steep declines in support in nearly all of South Africa’s major urban areas.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: A.N.C. Suffers Major Election Setback in South Africa
item.media:description: With a black party leader since last year, Mmusi Maimane, the Democratic Alliance appeared to have made inroads even in African National Congress strongholds.
item.description: For the African National Congress, it was the worst election since the party helped bring about the end of apartheid.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Young Syrian Torchbearer Highlights Brazil’s Embrace of Refugees
item.media:description: Hanan Dacka with her mother, Yuba Bkri, and baby sister, Yara, in their apartment in São Paulo, Brazil.
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.description: An antipathy many feel toward the Games turned to cheers when Hanan Dacka, one of the 2,300 Syrian refugees Brazil has admitted, carried the Olympic flame in Brasília.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees

item.title: Air of Graft Around Ex-Argentine Government Arouses Fury
item.media:description: José López, a former public works secretary, wearing a helmet and a bulletproof vest while under police custody in Buenos Aires.
item.description: The scandals are casting a pall over the achievements of the Front for Victory, the political party of the former president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: A ‘Good Refugee,’ His Song Suffused With Sorrow, Hopes to Touch Germany’s Heart
item.media:description: On a street in Wiesbaden, Germany, a woman recognized Mr. Ahmad from one of his concerts.
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.description: In a nation torn between embracing and fearing the migrants who have arrived in the past year, Aeham Ahmad has set himself the task of putting a human face on his fellow arrivals.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Bomb Wounds Russian-Backed Leader of Ukraine Separatist Region
item.description: A blast tore apart a car carrying Igor V. Plotnitsky, the president of the self-proclaimed Luhansk People’s Republic.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: From a Dacha Wall, a Clue to Raoul Wallenberg’s Cold War Fate
item.media:description: Vera Serova, the only grandchild of General Ivan A. Serov, worked with the Russian Military-Historical Society to create an exhibit about him linked to the publication of his diaries. They were found in suitcases hidden in a wall.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: The original K.G.B. chief’s diaries, long hidden, state outright for the first time that Mr. Wallenberg, a Swedish diplomat and war hero, was executed in a Moscow prison.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Military Success in Syria Gives Putin Upper Hand in U.S. Proxy War
item.media:description: The Russian defense minister, Sergei K. Shoigu, center, visited an air base in northern Syria in June. Russia’s air campaign against C.I.A.-backed rebels have forced them into retreat.
item.media:credit: Vadim Savitsky/Russian Defense Ministry, via Reuters
item.description: Russia has not only avoided a quagmire in Syria, its successes on the battlefield against C.I.A.-backed rebels have given it new leverage in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI, ANNE BARNARD and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: In Shift, Australia Pledges More Resources for Climate Research
item.media:description: The Cape Grim research station on the island of Tasmania plays a unique role in measuring greenhouse gases because of its location.
item.description: The measures do not completely reverse deep staff cuts to the country’s science agency that drew protests from scientists, but they appear to signal a turnaround.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (Australia)

item.title: A Question Lingers on the Irish-British Border: What’s Next?
item.media:description: Pat Cox, a former president of the European Parliament, at home in Blackrock, Dublin. Mr. Cox said membership in the European Union had played a crucial role in strengthening relations between Ireland and Britain.
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.description: Mutual membership in the European Union had helped Britain and Ireland repair their relationship. Now, Britain’s vote to leave the union promises to redefine it.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Talks to End War in Yemen Are Suspended
item.description: The suspension of negotiations after more than three months leaves a shaky cease-fire in doubt and threatens to deepen a humanitarian crisis.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Myanmar Measles Outbreak Kills 40 in Remote Villages
item.description: All but five of the victims were under the age of 15, officials said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: SAW NANG and RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Normandy Bar Fire Kills at Least 13 at Birthday Party
item.description: The fire, which appeared to be accidental, injured six others in the northwest city of Rouen, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Fire in Normandy Bar Kills at Least 13, French Police Say
item.description: The fire, which broke out at a birthday party in Rouen, injured six others.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Ahmed H. Zewail, Nobel-Prize-Winning Chemist, Dies at 70
item.media:description: Ahmed H. Zewail, left, in 1999 after being honored by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt for winning the Nobel Prize.
item.description: Dr. Zewail, a naturalized American citizen, was the first Arab to win a Nobel in any of the sciences, and he championed science in Egypt and the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH CHANG
item.category: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)

item.title: What Price to Keep France Safe? Perhaps a Nation’s Core Values, Many Fear
item.media:description: French soldiers patrol the Promenade des Anglais on Thursday in Nice, France. Security along the French Riviera and across France has been stepped up following recent terrorist attacks.
item.description: As a presidential election approaches, extreme measures, rejected for now, might be harder to fend off as the country struggles with an internal security problem.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: 13 Killed in Separatist Attack in Northeastern India
item.media:description: Indian security personnel carried a wounded person from the site of the attack, in the northeastern state of Assam, on Friday.
item.description: It was the first major assault in nearly two years in a restive part of the state of Assam, where an ethnic group has been clamoring for autonomy.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: U.S. Could Exceed Goal of Accepting 10,000 Syrian Refugees
item.media:description: Madiha Algothany and her husband, Mahmoud al-Rifai, and one of their children in Baltimore.
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.description: After a slow start and amid fierce political controversy, the Obama administration said on Friday that 8,000 Syrian refugees had arrived since October.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Syrians Seeking Asylum in South Korea Find Only a Cold Shoulder
item.media:description: Ahmad Barro, left, Ahmad al-Othman and Ahmad Khalifa last month in Yangju, South Korea. The men, all from Syria, expressed frustration as they talked about family members left in Aleppo.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: Wary of Muslim immigrants after attacks in Europe, South Korea lets 670 Syrians stay only on annual visas, limiting their ability to find jobs and barring them from benefits.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: The Particle That Wasn’t
item.media:description: The Large Hadron Collider at CERN in 2014.
item.description: Physicists working at the Large Hadron Collider reveal that mounds of data did not support the possibility of a new particle.
item.dc:creator: DENNIS OVERBYE

item.title: Syrian Girl Born Without an Eye Undergoes Surgery in Barcelona
item.description: Sham Aldaher will probably be able to leave the hospital by early next week, although more procedures will be required for her to receive a prosthetic, officials said.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Week of TV Trials in China Signals New Phase in Attack on Rights
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Zhou Shifeng, Gou Hongguo, Zhai Yanmin and Hu Shigen during their trials in Tianjin, China.
item.description: Legal experts and supporters denounced the hearings of four defendants, held on consecutive days in Tianjin, as grotesque show trials.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Black Lives Matter Activists Stage Protests Across Britain
item.description: Members of the emerging movement in the country demonstrated in London, Birmingham, Nottingham and other cities, responding to calls for a nationwide protest against racial injustice.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Sinosphere: Weighing the Strengths and Shortcomings of China’s Education System
item.media:description: High school seniors studying in preparation for the gaokao, the university entrance exam, in Lianyungang, China.
item.description: The economist Scott Rozelle, who wrote a study that challenges popular conceptions of Chinese education, explains why high schools are doing a better job than colleges.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Sinosphere: China Reins In Communist Youth League, and Its Alumni’s Prospects
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping in Beijing last month. The Communist Party has announced a major reorganization of its Youth League, a training ground for many officials who have been marginalized under Mr. Xi.
item.description: The league has served as a cradle for generations of Chinese leaders, who rose through it into the high ranks of the party.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: What in the World: The Face of Taiwan’s Past Is Slowly Fading From View
item.media:description: More than 200 statues of Chiang Kai-shek, the Chinese Nationalist leader who died in 1975, have been moved to a park near his mausoleum in Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan.
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.description: As the island has democratized, statues and busts of Chiang Kai-shek, the longtime president of the Republic of China, are gradually being either removed or relocated.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: What in the World: British Royal History, and Intrigue, in a Quaint German Town
item.media:description: The German town of Celle is an ancestral home of Britain’s royal family, the Windsors.
item.description: Celle, Germany, has played host to British royals on several occasions because of its role as an ancestral home of the House of Windsor.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: What in the World: A Mother’s Love? Of Course. Her Citizenship? Not So Fast.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; Photo by Glyphstock/shutterstock
item.description: Laws in 27 countries say that only fathers, not mothers, confer their nationality on a child. If Dad is dead or missing, Baby may wind up stateless.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Opinion: Trump, the Bad, Bad Businessman
item.media:description: Taking down the sign for the Trump Plaza Casino in Atlantic City in 2014, when it closed.
item.description: The real estate and casino developer I covered as a reporter in the 1990s was a disaster.
item.dc:creator: NEIL BARSKY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: For Putin, Disinformation Is Power
item.media:description: A Russian police officer during a rally in support of Vladimir V. Putin in Moscow in 2012.
item.description: When Americans gloated about winning the Cold War, they opened a door for Russians’ resentment — and Putin’s tactics.
item.dc:creator: ARKADY OSTROVSKY

item.title: Editorial: Stuck in Platitudes on Migration Crisis
item.media:description: Syrian refugees near the village of Idomeni, Greece.
item.description: Addressing the global exodus of refugees and migrants will require concrete, binding commitments.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Outstanding Issues: A Yemeni Teenager’s Trip to Estonia, by Way of Guantánamo
item.media:description: Ahmed Abdul Qader, a former Guantánamo Bay detainee, at Freedom Square in Tallinn, Estonia, in May.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The reporter Charlie Savage wrote about an ex-Guantánamo inmate’s resettlement; the story didn’t end when the article published.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Voices From Europe’s Far Right
item.media:description: “Our economy doesn’t increase along with the never-ending supply of immigrants,” wrote Mikael Jakobsen, 24, a law student in Aarhus, Denmark.
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of readers from across the Continent responded to our call to share their experiences as supporters of far-right parties.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
